MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Sligo Hospital Extension.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he can state when the new hospital extension will be opened at Sligo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Childers) Erskine Hamilton Childers
Speaker.P: The work on the new hospital extension at Sligo is practically completed and it is expected that patients will be in occupation of the new accommodation before the end of September.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Nurses Working Hours.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he is aware that very irregular hours are worked by nurses in several hospitals; and that some nurses finish night duty at 8 a.m. and resume duty at 2 p.m.; and what action he proposes to take to improve working hours.

Subject to adherence to the approved total hours of service, nurses' duty rosters are determined by the matron in each hospital having regard to the varying needs of the work situation at different periods of the day and night. I have had no recent complaints that these arrangements operate unreasonably from the nurses' point of view. If the Deputy will send me particulars of the case complained of and any other instances of attendance requirements which are causing difficulty, I will pursue the matter with the authorities concerned.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Regional Health Boards.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health when the regional health boards will be established.
The health boards regulations, 1970, provide for the establishment of the eight health boards on 1st October, 1970.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Faith Healer's Activities.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he has any observations to make concerning the attendance of large numbers of persons at the clinic of the faith healer (person named), with particular reference to the recent death of a person (name supplied) as reported.
I have some general observations to make.

There are, of course, certain disabilities imposed by law on persons who practise medicine without being registered as medical practitioners. Subject to those disabilities it is not illegal to practise faith healing. Neither is it illegal for a person to attend a faith healer.

Persons who attend faith healers, however, do so at their own risk. My strong advice to anyone who is ill is to look to his family doctor, or the specialist or hospital to which he is referred, for care and treatment. In this way he can be sure of obtaining all the advantages which accrue from modern medicine.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mentally Retarded Children.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he has considered the extension of hospitalisation for mentally retarded children at Sligo as the facilities there are not adequate to deal with the demand.
It is expected that work will commence in the near future on a scheme to provide an additional 60 places at Cregg House, Sligo, for severely mentally handicapped boys and girls.

MainHeading.P: I have also approved of a further extension at this centre to provide accommodation for 100 adult mentally handicapped females and preliminary planning work has commenced in consultation with the Order.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ambulance Services.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will arrange for the provision of suitably trained ambulance personnel throughout the country who could give attention to patients which is at present given by nurses who have to be called from duty for this purpose.

In the case of accident calls made on ambulance centres in the rural areas and where specifically requested by the referring doctor in other cases, it has been the practice to arrange for a nurse to accompany the ambulance driver when answering the call. This ensures that skilled nursing attention is available to the victim at the scene of the accident and during the journey to hospital. Ambulance drivers are given practical training in essential first-aid and resuscitation procedures but it is not proposed at the moment that the attendance of a nurse on accident calls should be discontinued. I might add, however, that all aspects of the ambulance services, including that mentioned by the Deputy, are at present being actively examined by the consultative council on the ambulance services which will be submitting recommendations to me from time to time.

Would the Minister not consider it most unfair to ask that in accident cases an ambulance driver, who must drive the ambulance, should also be required to look after patients in the back of the ambulance?

This is a very complex matter. The Irish Nurses' Organisation have their views on it and the medical fraternity have their views. As I have said, I am examining the question in what I hope is a rational way.
I hope the Minister will not agree to take nurses out of ambulances and ask the ambulance drivers to look after the patients?
I shall not do anything that I think is foolish.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Tranquilliser Drugs.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will elaborate on his statement in Limerick last week concerning the issue of tranquilliser drugs under the current medical card system.

I could not elaborate in reply to a Parliamentary question on the statement referred to except to say that my general comment on the use of the preparations referred to did not apply specifically to persons covered by medical cards in the Dublin area. This information was given purely for purposes of illustration.

I dealt with this question in considerable detail in introducing the Estimate for my Department in Dáil Éireann on 8th April last. I would refer the Deputy to columns 1058 to 1060 of the Official Report of that date.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Carlow Dentures List.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the number of people on the waiting list for dentures in County Carlow.

The number of persons on the waiting list for dentures in County Carlow is about 230. Due to the shortage of dental staff the local health authority finds it necessary to restrict the supply of dentures to priority groups. Steps taken to fill the vacancy for a whole-time dental officer have not, so far, been successful but efforts to fill the vacancy will continue to be made.

Would the Minister undertake to do something urgently about this matter? It is a very long time outstanding and the waiting list is growing. Twelve months ago there were over 200 on it and there are now 230. Some of these people have been a number of years on the waiting list.

I am aware of the position. The position for a second dental officer has been approved and no one has been found. We also approved private dentists doing sessional business through the local authority and no one has been found. I am sending a dental officer of my Department to see whether we can secure a temporary appointment of a dental officer or obtain the services of private dentists on a part-time basis either from inside or outside the county. I am doing everything I can.
How long has the council been looking for the second dentist?
Some considerable time, I think.
Surely it is obvious some alternative effort must be made.
There has been a post for a whole-time dental officer vacant since March, 1968.
There have been 200 people waiting for dentures.

We cannot find anyone to fill the post. As the Deputy knows from my speech on the Health Estimate, the salaries for whole-time dental officers now approximate within reason to the salaries of whole-time dental officers in Great Britain, so it is not a question of salary. We just have not been able to fill the post.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Northern Ireland Situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for External Affairs whether the raising of any issue connected with the situation in Northern Ireland is under consideration for the forthcoming session of the UN; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for External Affairs (Dr. Hillery) Patrick J. Hillery
Speaker.P: The question of taking action in the United Nations in relation to the north depends on developments. The matter is capable of consideration at any time.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Irish Prisoners in England.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for External Affairs whether he is aware of alleged harsh treatment of six Irish prisoners in England who have been jailed in connection with arms charges; and whether his Department will make representations in the matter and inquire into these allegations.

When inquiries were made of the British Home Office our embassy was informed that Mr. O'Sullivan did not wish any information about himself to be disclosed by the Home Office to the embassy. In these circumstances Mr. O'Sullivan has made it impossible for me to make further representations in the matter.
The same is true in the case of Mr. Conor Lynch.
No allegations of ill-treatment have been brought to my attention in the cases of Barry Bruton, Alan McIlveen, Eamonn Smullen and Thomas Doherty.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Are we to take it that the Department was willing to make any representations that might be necessary but there was no co-operation from the people interned?
We have made several inquiries and representations but Mr. O'Sullivan and Mr. Lynch do not want any information about themselves given to our embassy by the Home Office in Britain.
Is the Minister not aware that there is considerable concern in this country about these people?

I have answered the question. I am aware of the allegations made but when I tried to do something about it the man said he did not want the Home Office in Britain to tell our embassy anything about him. It makes it quite impossible to do anything in that case.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Central Bank Report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance whether any Government response by way of remedial action is under consideration following the latest Central Bank Report.

asked the Minister for Finance if he will comment on the report of the Central Bank of Ireland for the year ended 1970 which stated that the threat which inflation poses to the Irish economy has, unfortunately, become, more and more acute and that competitiveness is being eroded by a degree of price and cost inflation which is greater even than in the United Kingdom and much greater than in the EEC countries generally; and if he will state the measures he intends to take to correct this very serious position.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Colley) George Colley
Speaker.P: With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 20 and 21 together.

The Government have time and again drawn attention to the inflationary pressures referred to in the Central Bank annual report and to the fact that as a result of these pressures the competitiveness of our goods and services in external markets is being undermined. The Taoiseach in his speech opening the debate on the motion for the Adjournment for the Summer Recess dealt with the situation in detail. He called for restraint by all sectors to avoid pricing ourselves out of both home and export markets and thus threatening jobs and living standards. Inflation is, admittedly, a world-wide phenomenon but it is imperative, given our dependence on increased exports for greater growth and more employment opportunities, that our prices and costs should not be running ahead of those of our competitors.

As indicated by the Taoiseach, if moderation in seeking income increases is not exercised and there are signs of an unsustainable increase in the balance of payments deficit the Government will have no hesitation in introducing further restrictive measures.
Were the Government not aware of this inflation until this report came out? The Minister has been kind of boasting about it in this House recently.
As I have indicated in the reply I have given, the Government have time and again drawn attention to these inflationary pressures which were referred to in that report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: Am I to understand that, having considered the report of the Central Bank, the Government and the Minister for Finance are satisfied that no remedial action is now required to keep the economy in check?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: The Minister said as much.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Gold Reserve.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance how it is that the gold reserve of £28,236,000 in the Central Bank at 31st March, 1969, has been so reduced that it amounted to only £303,000 at 31st March, 1970.

The gold holding of £28,236,000 to which the Deputy refers was included in the balance sheet of the Central Bank's general fund on 31st March, 1969. Of this sum, an amount of £11.5 million was transferred to the Bank's Legal Tender Note Fund in which it is still held. A further amount, namely £16.4 million, was sold for reinvestment of the proceeds in foreing currencies and foreign securities as part of the bank's continuous task of structuring the external reserves to the best national advantage.

Does the Minister not realise that this resembles the time in 1916 when the gold reserve in this country in the Bank of Ireland was sent across to the Bank of England? Does he not realise that gold in the hand is worth four pieces of paper in the bush? Does the Minister not realise that gold is a reality and that paper assets are not the same thing at all?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: In view of our application to join the EEC and assuming that we enter the EEC it is quite probable that that bloc's currency will be based on a gold or quasi-gold standard and in view of that would the Minister not consider that the selling of all our gold reserves is a very short-sighted policy?

No; the indications in regard to likely developments in the EEC—and they are by no means certain yet—are that the most likely development is that there would be fixed parity between the currencies of all of the member States. A less likely alternative is that there would be a common currency but, in effect, they would be the same thing. The question of the unit being based on gold is quite a different matter altogether. I have indicated that there was £11½ million worth of gold transferred. This was really a technical transfer arising out of the transfer from the Minister for Finance to the Central Bank of the reserve position of the International Monetary Fund under the Bretton Woods Agreement (Amendment) Act, 1969. As regards the other sales, it is the responsibility of the Central Bank to use these to the best national advantage and I am satisfied that that is what the Central Bank are doing.
Question No. 23.

Does the Minister not realise that this is much the same kind of transaction as the agreement that the British would supply us with shipping to bring in adequate supplies here during the last war and we know what happened then? It is the same kind of thing. A sell-out.
No. I do not agree.
Question No. 23. I have called Question No. 23.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Clare Vocational School Teachers.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware that the allocation of teachers to County Clare Vocational Education Committee is inadequate; and that unless the present allocation of teachers is increased, schools may have to be closed down and it will be impossible to carry on their teaching programme as planned; and if he will reconsider the matter with a view to increasing the number of teachers available to the committee.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Faulkner) Padraig Faulkner
Speaker.P: The method of determining teacher requirements by reference to a pupil/teacher ratio is an internationally recognised one. The fact that it has been introduced in respect of vocational schools for the first time this year has given rise to a good deal of misunderstanding and, I regret to say, some misrepresentation. I should like, first of all therefore, to make it clear that the pupil/teacher ratio has been applied to all vocational education committees and not just to some of them. Secondly, I should like to point out that the actual ratio adopted is a generous one.

The examination of the position in vocational schools shows that in fact there are very wide disparities between schools and between schemes which are not easily explainable. The allocation of teachers made recently to each vocational education committee was composed of the sum of the following three elements:—
(a) the committee's projected enrolment of whole-time day continuation pupils in September, 1970, divided by 17.5;

MainHeading.P: (b) the committee's projected teaching hours for apprenticeship and adult education work divided by 800 to give the required number of full-time equivalent teachers for these classes;
(c) the number of headmasters in the committee's scheme.

Allowance was also made by the Department for any teaching services provided by a committee to secondary schools under co-operation arrangements or for any non-school services provided by a committee.

The position is that some committees have been operating by reference to class sizes which are far too low and consequently feel that the Department's allocation is inadequate. There is no reason why any committee should in any way curtail or restrict their projected apprenticeship or adult education programmes. As I have indicated, full allowance was given in respect of each committee's projection of its needs in this matter.

In these circumstances I feel that the teacher allocation sanctioned by my Department is adequate to meet each committee's needs provided they operate on the basis of reasonable class sizes. It has also been made clear to committees that the Department will be prepared to reconsider the matter on the basis of an examination in depth of the position in each of their schools where there are any circumstances of a special nature. Such an examination is in fact proceeding in a number of cases.

Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that the Clare Vocational Education Committee and the parents and pupils are alarmed at this method of curtailment? It would in fact mean the curtailment of the scheme which they have prepared and the abandonment of 3,200 hours which could be availed of by the adult pupils in the night classes and under the suggestion——
We cannot have a speech on this.
Is the Minister aware that the Department's suggestion will mean that rural areas will not benefit and, in fact, they will be victimised but there will be no curtailment in the built-up areas?

I do not accept what the Deputy says. I have already pointed out that the staff allocation proposed by us is generous. In fact, we are proposing a pupil/teacher ratio which they do not hope to reach in Scotland until 1975-1976 and everybody accepts that Scotland is very far advanced educationally. As I mentioned in my reply, our allocation takes into account not only the whole-time day classes but the part-time and evening classes, including the adult education courses. We are prepared, as I also said in my reply, to examine in depth cases of schools where there are any circumstances of a special nature.

I appreciate the Minister's anxiety in this scheme and I know that, in common with Deputies and with vocational committees, he is anxious that we should save the west. Therefore I would ask him to have second thoughts and to allow the full allocation of teachers to remote areas like County Clare.
I have already explained that I am willing to have any case examined where there is a particular problem.

Speaker.P: I am not aware of any particular hardship caused by the present arrangement. I am, however, aware that if any other method were adopted it would leave itself open to widespread abuse. It is, of course, possible for herd owners with herds in different areas to have different herd numbers.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Meath Sheep Dipping Font.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he is prepared to sanction the provision of a sheep dipping font for the fair green of Oldcastle, County Meath.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: The provision of public sheep dipping facilities in County Meath is the function of the county council.

My Department operates a scheme under which grants are made available to county councils towards the cost of provision of such facilities. No application has been received in the Department from Meath County Council for a grant under the scheme in respect of a dipping tank to be provided at Oldcastle. If and when it is it will be considered.
Do I understand from the Minister that no application has been made?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: That is right.

I should like the Minister to note that application has been made though it may not have reached his Department yet. Strong representations were made to me by local residents that it would not be in the interests of health to impose this upon them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: If Meath County Council make an application under the scheme it will be considered.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Lamb Subsidy.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he will give consideration to representatives from Sligo-Leitrim regarding the changing of some of the centres, details of which have already been published, for the purpose of checking on lambs for the lamb subsidy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: Sympathetic consideration was given to all requests for inspection centres under the sheep subsidy schemes which were received before the lists of centres were sent for publication. There are 87 centres in Sligo-Leitrim this year as against 67 last year and it is considered that the needs of sheep owners in the area have been adequately catered for.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Cavan Industries.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce what is the position regarding the proposed establishment of a new industry at Mullagh, County Cavan; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Lalor) Patrick J. Lalor
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Lalor)
Speaker.P: As industrial proposals must be treated as confidential, I am not in a position to make an announcement on the subject.
asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce what is the latest position regarding the proposed establishment of ancillary industry at Kingscourt, County Cavan.

I understand that the Greenmount and Boyne Linen Co. Ltd. held a press reception on 1st July, 1970, at which they announced the opening of a new factory at Kingscourt for the manufacture of dresses, jeans and jackets. I have no further information on the matter.
Could I ask the Minister when he will be in a position to give us some more definite information?
As soon as the proposal is actually ready to go ahead. There is a degree of confidentiality required between the proposed industrialist and the IDA and this confidentiality must be respected.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Laois Employment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce what steps he is now taking to provide a worthwhile industry which will provide the much-needed male employment in the town of Portlaoise, County Laois.

The Industrial Development Authority have been giving special attention to the attraction of industry to Portlaoise and other midland towns and these efforts are continuing. The Deputy must realise, however, that the ultimate selection of the location for an industrial undertaking is a matter for the promoters themselves. It is for local interests, therefore, to continue their efforts to attract private enterprise to set up industries and they can be assured of my constant vigilance and co-operation in this regard.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Laois-Offaly Industrial Grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he is now in a position to declare Laois-Offaly as qualifying for industrial grants and State aid on a par with all other under-developed areas in the country; and if he will make a statement in this regard.
The question of the designation of Laois-Offaly for the purposes of industrial development incentives is still under consideration.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Leitrim Industry.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if in view of the serious depopulation of County Leitrim he has any proposals for the provision of an industry in the county which would give employment at home to young men and girls who have to emigrate at present.

I am aware of one proposal for the establishment of an industry in County Leitrim. Three firms have been approved for assistance under the Small Industries Programme since 1st April, 1970, bringing the total number of approvals for the county to 24. A further eight applications under the programme are under consideration.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Closure of Factory.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he is aware that the receiver has now closed a factory (name supplied); and if, in view of the hardship being caused to so many dismissed employees and the urgent need for industries in the town, he will give this matter his urgent attention with the hope of having this factory re-opened.

I had been keeping in touch with the problems of this factory and I know that it has now closed down. As the Deputy is, no doubt, aware, unsuccessful efforts were made since the firm went into receivership, to find a suitable purchaser who would take over the mill as a going concern.

The Deputy will be aware of my views in the matter arising from the discussion I had this morning with a deputation of workers, which he and Deputy Brosnan attended and which was arranged by the Minister for Defence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: Might I just say that in the question as I wrote it the town of Fermoy was mentioned? For some reason it does not appear in the question here. This applies to the town of Fermoy also. For the umpteenth time I tell the Minister once again that male industrial employment is badly needed in the town of Fermoy and will he and his Department give the matter serious consideration?

As I have already said, the Deputy will be fully aware of my views in this regard. I make no bones about saying that there is no doubt but that there is full acceptance of the fact that there is need for further male industrial employment in Fermoy. I should point out that it was not I who was responsible for the removal of the town from the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: I appreciate the Minister's assurance and his interest and I want to put on record our appreciation of his giving us an hour and a half of his time today.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Garda Rent Allowances.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if the negotiations concerning the implementation of the rent allowances for gardaí arising from the Conroy Commission's Report have as yet been completed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.P: It has been already decided to pay the rent allowances recommended by the Conroy Commission in respect of those members not living in official accommodation and this decision has been conveyed to the Garda representatives. Negotiations are still in progress, however, about the grading of the official accommodation which is provided in different areas and the charges to be made in respect of the accommodation of different grades once the grading has been agreed on.

A meeting of the Conciliation Council of the Garda Síochána was held on the 14th April at which it was decided to set up a working party to examine the question of the classification of the accommodation and to leave the question of charges to be discussed at the Conciliation Council. The working party made their report on 17th June, 1970.
A meeting of the council is to be held early in August at which it is excepted that the rates will be determined and, if agreement is reached, the new scheme will be set in motion forthwith.
Will the Minister sanction payment immediately agreement is reached?
I have already said I will. Assuming agreement is reached at the August meeting, and I hope it will be, sanction will be forthcoming at once and payments will be retrospective to 1st April last.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Army Pensions.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence why the pensions of retiring Army personnel are withheld until they vacate married quarters when the Department has no scheme to seek alternative accommodation for such personnel and local authorities make no special provision for these cases.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cronin) Gerry Cronin
Speaker.P: Defence Forces Regulations provide for the recovery, as a public debt, of charges in respect of the use of quarters, furniture, water, gas and/or electricity by former members of the Defence Forces. While unauthorised possession is continued, it is not possible to finalise those charges. The Defence Forces (Pensions) Scheme provides for the recovery of such charges from pension and for the withholding of pension until the amount of the deduction is ascertained.

The provision of houses for ex-military personnel is a matter for the local authorities concerned who are generally co-operative in this regard. Soldiers who are about to be released from the Permanent Defence Force are advised by the military authorities to apply to the local authorities concerned for re-housing. Following the making of each such application, my Department requests the local authority to give favourable consideration to each individual case.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Middle East Service Allowance.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence why officers serving in the Middle East are not paid the same allowances as officers in Cyprus; and if he intends to meet their grievance having in mind the dangerous nature of their missions.

The nature of the mission and the conditions of service in the Middle East were entirely different from those in Cyprus and the question of the payment by this country of an overseas allowance to the officers concerned did not arise.
Having regard, however, to the changed circumstances in that area, the matter has been under review and a decision is expected shortly.
Would the Minister say if the reason is that the overseas allowance paid in Cyprus is paid by the United Nations?
The Middle East is the direct responsibility of the United Nations.
Would they not refund the amount of the overseas allowance to the Irish Government?
I think that is unlikely. There are other countries not providing allowances for their troops in the Middle East.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Waterford Houses.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the number of houses completed by Waterford County Council in 1957 and 1969; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Local Government (Mr. Cunningham) Liam Cunningham
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Local Government (Mr. Cunningham)
Speaker.P: Waterford County Council completed five houses in 1957 and 38 houses in 1969. At the end of last month the county council had work in progress on 76 dwellings and had 320 more houses at tender and planning stages.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the number of houses completed by Waterford Corporation in the years 1957 and 1969; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Waterford Corporation completed 74 houses in 1957 and 84 houses in 1969. At present they have a scheme for 160 houses and 26 developed sites for private houses at tender stage and are preparing plans for another 222 houses.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Planning Appeals.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the number of planning refusal appeals at present unfinalised in his Department; and the number on this date last year.

The number of undecided appeals against decisions of planning authorities on application for permission for development at the 30th June, 1970, was 1,775. The corresponding figure at the 30th June, 1969, was 1,455.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Louth Houses.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the number of houses and their location, at present with his Department from Louth County Council for sanction; when the applications were made; and when they will be sanctioned.

The only local authority housing proposal which is before my Department at present from Louth County Council is a revised proposal for the acceptance of a tender for 34 local authority houses and for 36 private housing sites at Dunleer. This proposal was received in my Department on the 21st instant and is being examined. I will give a decision on it shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Mayo Housing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lenehan Mr. J. Lenehan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the present position regarding proposals of Mayo County Council for the erection of ten dwellinghouses in Belmullet town.
I understand that sketch plans for a scheme of ten houses in Belmullet are being prepared by the county council and will be submitted to my Department shortly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lenehan Mr. J. Lenehan
Speaker.P: In view of the fact that these plans have been under examination for the past 20 years, can the Parliamentary Secretary take any action to ensure that this discredited council will take the necessary steps to have the houses provided in the near future? Can any pressure be put on them because we have failed?
The Department have been pressing Mayo County Council to take steps to alleviate the housing problem that exists there.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kerry Housing Schemes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he has any proposals from Kerry County Council regarding a housing scheme for Caherciveen.

asked the Minister for Local Government if all arrangements have been completed between his Department and the Kerry County Council for the erection of five cottages in Caherciveen; and, if so, when erection will start.
With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 55 and 56 together.
The county council's proposals were approved by me on the 6th May last. I have no information as to the commencement date of the scheme.
asked the Minister for Local Government what proposals he has received from Kerry County Council regarding a housing scheme at Park road, Killarney, County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government what proposals Kerry County Council and the National Building Agency have for the provision of houses for industrial workers and others in Killarney on lands acquired for housing; and whether it is expected that the proposed scheme will be carried out during the current financial year.
With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 57 and 58 together.

Negotiations have been proceeding between interested bodies with a view to the provision, by the National Building Agency Limited, of houses for industrial workers and others on a site owned by Kerry County Council at Park Road, Killarney. I understand that house plans have been agreed and that a revised lay-out plan will be discussed shortly between officers of the agency and the council. I cannot say at this stage when work on the scheme will be carried out.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Authority Property Maintenance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lenehan Mr. J. Lenehan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if any action can be taken by him to compel local authorities to maintain the exterior appearance and condition of premises owned or occupied by them at a standard at least as good as that of premises held by private ownership in such areas, to ensure that local authority held properties will not have a detimental effect on tidy town competition decisions.

I am not aware that the standard of maintenance of local authority premises compares unfavourably with that of adjoining premises held by private ownership. While I have no statutory functions in the matter, if the Deputy has any specific case in mind I will have the matter taken up with the local authority concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lenehan Mr. J. Lenehan
Speaker.P: In view of the shocking exterior condition of practically all the premises owned by local authorities in the rural areas, would the Minister agree to circulate to local authorities a request that they should bring the premises up to acceptable standards? I can assure the Parliamentary Secretary that these buildings are eyesores and he would see many of them if he comes to my area or to any area west of the Shannon.
If the Deputy brings a specific case to my notice I shall look into the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Dublin Concrete Mixer.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is now in a position to state his decision concerning the oral hearing of a planning appeal under section 5 of the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1963, in regard to a proposed ready-mix concrete plant at Newtownpark Avenue, Blackrock, County Dublin; and what action he proposes to take in the matter.
I have not yet made a decision on this reference.
Can the Parliamentary Secretary give an indication when a decision will be made on this appeal?

An oral hearing took place on the 28th and 29th April last. The company concerned took legal proceedings and the court case was held on 16th July. A decision in this instance will not be given until the 16th August.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bull Island (Dublin) Development.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government what proposals are envisaged for the further development of the North Bull Island, Dublin; and if, in view of the construction of the causeway leading to the island, it is intended to provide car park facilities for the large number of motorists frequenting this resort.

The North Bull Island is included in a list of open spaces in the possession of Dublin Corporation which are the subject of general development objectives in the draft development plan for Dublin. There is no information in my Department about the corporation's detailed proposals for the further development (including the provision of car parking facilities) of the Bull Island.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Raheny (Dublin) Development.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government what proposals are envisaged for the further development of St. Anne's Park, Raheny, Dublin.

St. Anne's Park is included in a list of open spaces in the possession of Dublin Corporation which are the subject of general development objectives in the draft development plan for Dublin. There is no information in my Department about the corporation's detailed proposals for further development at St. Anne's.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Road Fund.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the total amount paid into the Road Fund for the year 1969-70; how much was collected in Dublin city; and how much was paid in grants out of the Road Fund to the Dublin road authority.
Following is the information requested:—

Total amount lodged to the credit of the Road Fund in the financial year 1969-70 was £12,000,654; the amount collected by Dublin Corporation, which is the licensing authority for the city and the county including Dún Laoghaire, was £4,643,490; and the amount paid in grants out of the Road Fund to Dublin Corporation, Dún Laoghaire Corporation and Dublin County Council was £1,193,306.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Corporation Land Pool.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the total acreage in the land pool held by Dublin Corporation; and whether he will arrange that, pending development, suitable areas of this land be rented to industrious city dwellers anxious to produce much-needed vegetables.
The information sought in the first part of the question is not available in my Department.

MainHeading.P: I understand that land held by Dublin Corporation which is not immediately required by them is normally let on a short-term basis for either grazing or tillage. The corporation operate one scheme of allotments at Finglas under the Acquisition of Land (Allotments) Acts. It is a matter for them to consider whether the provision of additional allotments is called for.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Private Motor Cars.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will state the current number of private motor cars under current licence; and the number of cars licensed in the greater Dublin area.
The total number of private motor cars under current licence on 10th August, 1969, was 353,961; and the number of private cars licensed in Dublin City and County was 107,205.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Westmeath Road.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will state his reason for refusing to make an order closing a disused portion of public road T 31 at Clogharboy, Athlone, County Westmeath.

The order made by Westmeath County Council under section 76 of the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1963, provided for the extinguishment of the public right of way over a distance of 483 yards of road which has been replaced by a new stretch of road. At the public local inquiry held in connection with the order, evidence was given on behalf of the council that due to the need to preserve access rights for some of the property owners affected by the order, the council wanted to modify the proposal to confine the extinguishment to a length of 325 feet of road and to retain the public right of way over the remainder. As I had no power to modify the order in this way, I had to reject the order in its entirety.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Clare Road Improvements.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government when the urgently-needed road improvements at the junction of the Limerick, Shannon Airport and Ennis Roads, Shannon, County Clare, will be commenced.

Work on the improvements referred to cannot be commenced pending the determination of proceedings for the compulsory acquisition of the necessary land by the Clare County Council. The objections and the evidence given at a public local inquiry into the proposed compulsory acquisition are at present under consideration in my Department.

Will the Parliamentary Secretary endeavour to expedite the decision of his Department on this matter, not only in relation to the junction but, as I should have included in my question, the three-quarter mile stretch of local road towards Limerick? I would stress to the Parliamentary Secretary that this local road area is an absolute disgrace and it is particularly objectionable having regard to the proximity of Shannon Airport.
I would point out to the Parliamentary Secretary that the fact that the rest of the road is good makes it all the more hazardous because people do not expect to meet this bad stretch of road.
I will pass on the request to the Minister.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kerry Houses.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government when, approximately, work will commence on the building of 34 houses for Killarney Urban District Council at Ardshanavooley, Killarney, in respect of which his Department sanctioned the raising of the loan for the purchase of the land and for the building of the houses.
I do not know when work is likely to be started on these houses. The date of commencement is a matter between the housing authority and the contractor.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government what proposals the National Building Agency has for the erection of houses in Kenmare, County Kerry, for industrial workers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the present position regarding the proposed 24 house scheme to be built in Kenmare by Kerry County Council; and if he will confirm that it will not be necessary for Kerry County Council to raise a loan specifically for this purpose.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - South Tipperary Housing Schemes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the present position in respect of the following housing schemes which have been proposed by Tipperary South Riding County Council—Cappawhite, Cahir, Two-Mile-Bridge (Jocker), Clonmel, Mullinahone, Rosegreen, Marlfield, Bansha, Ballyclerihan, The Commons, Thurles, Fethard (Newport), Two-Mile-Bridge (O'Connell), Ardfinnan, Burncourt, Newcastle and New Inn.

I have not received any proposals for the remaining schemes.

asked the Minister for Local Government when tenders for sanction were submitted to him, and when such sanction is likely to be given, in respect of 16 houses at Golden and four houses at Grangemockler, County Tipperary.
The housing authority's proposal to accept a tender for four houses at Grangemockler was received in my Department last week.

With regard to Golden, I have not yet received a proposal to accept a tender for the proposed scheme of 16 houses but I have received last week a revised proposal for the acceptance of a tender for the scheme of six houses. Both this proposal and the one for Grangemockler are under examination and my decisions on them will be given as soon as possible.
asked the Minister for Local Government when the plans for six houses at Bawnmore, Cashel, County Tipperary, were submitted to him; and when approval may be expected.

These plans were submitted to my Department on the 5th May, 1970. I was advised that the proposed site was unsuitable for a housing scheme and the housing authority were so informed on the 16th June last.

asked the Minister for Local Government when the plans for a group of houses at Dundrum, County Tipperary, were first submitted to him; the number of houses involved; and if he will make a statement on the reason for delay in getting past the planning stage in this area.
No plans have been submitted to me for a scheme of houses in Dundrum.

asked the Minister for Local Government when applications for approval of loans were made to him and when such approval is likely to be given in respect of (a) the sanctioned tender for 16 houses at Fethard, (b) the sanctioned tender for eight houses at Kilsheelan, Clonmel, and (c) the sanctioned tender for four houses at Nodstown, Cashel.

The housing authority's proposals for the financing of these schemes were included in their application for a composite loan of £125,000 which was submitted originally on the 18th July, 1969. In accordance with normal practice sanction to the loan proposals for these schemes, which was issued on 17th instant, was deferred until the acceptance of tenders for the schemes had been approved by me.

asked the Minister for Local Government how many of the 80 dwellings estimated by the Cashel housing authority in March, 1968, as being necessary to the period ending 31st March, 1971, have, in fact, so far been provided; and if he will make a statement on the present position.

The assessment made by Cashel Urban District Council in March, 1968, was an estimate of the number of private and local authority houses that might fall to be required to meet accumulated and prospective needs in the period ending 31st March, 1971. I am not in a position to say how many private houses have so far been provided in the urban administrative area as statistics of private housing completions are not compiled in a form which would enable me to give this information. With regard to the provision of local authority houses, the formulation of scheme proposals to meet needs is a matter for the local housing authority. Their latest progress report indicates that they have plans for a scheme of 15 houses in hands and their proposals for the provision of 27 developed building sites for private houses were approved on the 20th February last.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kerry Housing.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he has received proposals from the Kerry County Council for the erection of a group of houses at Milltown, County Kerry.
I have received no such proposals.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Housing Sanction.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if, in regard to housing, Departmental sanction is required in general for (1) selection of site, (2) plans, (3) tenders, and (4) loans; and whether he will eliminate unnecessary delays arising therefrom.

Housing authorities do not require my sanction to the acquisition by agreement of housing sites which comply in general with recommended standards. Because of the need to maintain close control on building costs, the agreement of my Department to plans and to the acceptance of tenders for housing schemes is necessary. My sanction to the borrowing of money for housing purposes is required. Procedures for the documentation and submission of proposals for local authority housing schemes are kept under review and it is intended, subject to the requirements of my overall responsibility for the control of local authority housing, to maintain the present trend towards progressive reduction in the amount of detailed control operated by my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Meath Housing Schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fox Mr. Fox Mr. Conlan Mr. Conlan
Speaker.P: and Mr. Fox asked the Minister for Local Government the present position regarding the proposed housing scheme for Drumconrath, County Meath.
I am awaiting Meath County Council's proposal to accept a tender for this scheme. The scheme was approved by me last April.
asked the Minister for Local Government what proposals if any, there are before his Department for the provision of houses at Crossakill, Kells, County Meath.

There is a great housing shortage in that district. Would the Parliamentary Secretary impress on the Meath County Council—of which I am not a member—to get down to work and get on with this urgent job without any more delay?
Even if the Deputy is not a member of the Meath County Council, he might succeed in saying a word in the ears of some of the members of that council.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Price of Housing Land.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government whether control of the price of land for house building purposes is under consideration.

A general examination of all aspects of the problem of building land prices is being undertaken in my Department. At this stage, I am not in a position to state what action it may be decided to take in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Taoiseach, Deputy Andrews, called for action on this matter last weekend? Is he further aware of the general election call of the Labour Party in 1969 that there should be control of the price of land used for the building of houses? Could he give us any further information about the kind of examination which is going on in his Department at present in this connection?

Naturally, I am aware of the general problems created by a number of factors in the building industry—land being one of them. Land prices and other factors affecting the building programme are being very closely examined by the Department and steps are being taken——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: In the Dublin area at present it is reckoned that one-third of the cost of new houses is directly attributable to the cost of the land on which these houses are built. Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that, if we are to build more houses, then we shall have to control the price of building land?
I am not aware that the percentage is correct
A recent study of a significant number of schemes in Dublin, both council and private, gave a figure of 37 per cent of the cost of the houses as attributable to land costs.
One Deputy says one-third and another Deputy says 37 per cent.
If I secure the report on this survey and send a copy of it to the Parliamentary Secretary will he agree to submit it to his Department?
We are aware of all the factors militating against increased house production——
When will the study come to fruition?
Next question.
This is urgent. We are entitled to particulars. The position is getting worse all the time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: A study is in progress. We do not know when it is likely to conclude.
The Deputy is not entitled to make a speech on a supplementary question.
We are entitled to have this information.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Surely we are entitled to be given the information?
There have been a good many separte questions.
The key question here is when this study is likely to be completed. The Parliamentary Secretary must have some estimate of the time. One does not have open-ended inquiries.
I cannot say when the study will be completed.
Would the Parliamentary Secretary agree to check up on this, and communicate with the Deputies concerned, if he has not the information with him?
Yes, I will.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: In view of the unsatisfactory nature of the Parliamentary Secretary's reply, I wish to give notice that I propose to raise the subject matter of this question on the Adjournment tonight.
The Chair will communicate with the Deputy. There are already two questions before this one.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ballybrack (Dublin) Purchase Houses.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if, in view of the anticipated increased contract price for the 140 tenant-purchase houses of Dún Laoghaire Borough Corporation at Ballybrack, County Dublin, and the limitations of State grants available, he will sanction a tenant-purchase loan (repayment basis) in excess of £3,000 to mitigate the hardship which will be suffered otherwise by those obliged to place very substantially higher deposits.

The statutory limit applicable to house purchase loans made by local authorities in the Dublin area is £3,000. In view of the fact that the prices of the houses referred to by the Deputy are lower than the general average prevailing for comparable houses in the Dublin area and of the special facilities which Dún Laoghaire Corporation provided free for the purchasers of these houses in placing and supervising contracts and in the general administration of the project, I am not satisfied that the making to these purchasers of loans higher than those available to persons purchasing houses in the open market would be justified.

May I put it to the Parliamentary Secretary that it seems likely, on the basis of information available within the Dún Laoghaire Borough Corporation, that these houses will now cost another £400 per house over the period of the contract under the prices variation clause. On that basis, surely he appreciates that these tenant purchase houses are being purchased by persons with very limited incomes and savings and that it will be quite beyond their capacity to pay £600 or £700 as a deposit? The matter is quite serious because some of these houses are now due for occupancy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H.P. Dockrell Mr. H.P. Dockrell
Speaker.P: May I ask if the Minister has received a letter from Dún Laoghaire asking for the figure of £3,000 to be increased and, if so, what consideration he has given to that matter?
I cannot answer the second supplementary because I do not know.
It was sent all right.

With regard to the first supplementary, in view of the special facilities already given in the matters I mentioned, it would be hard to justify not having this purchase scheme as proposed. It will mean increased prices.

The Parliamentary Secretary has facilities open to him to give sanction as this is a tenant purchase house scheme on a notional repayment basis. If he were to sanction a price in excess of £3,000 he would get rid of a very alarming situation in which people might be obliged to opt out of tenant purchase and would have to be rehoused by Dún Laoghaire Borough Corporation in the near future at a higher cost.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Sligo-Leitrim House Loans.

House purchase loan schemes are operated by Sligo Corporation and by Sligo and Leitrim County Councils. Loans to eligible applicants under these schemes may amount to 95 per cent of the value of a house as determined by the local authority—or 99 per cent in the case of a local authority tenant surrendering his tenancy—subject to a maximum in any case of £2,700.

Separate statistics for operations under subsection 2 (b) of section 16 of the Housing Act, 1966, are only available as from January, 1967. The numbers of grants paid since then were:—

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Authority Housing.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if, in respect of subsidiable limits for local authority housing, he will amplify his reply of 21st May, 1970 to the effect that these limits have been revised four times since 1948-49; the dates and nature of the revisions and how the present subsidy of £106 for 50 years as compared with £57 in 1953 is computed.

Since 1948-49 the subsidisable limit for a serviced house has been increased as follows:— From 31st October, 1950, £950; from 1st May, 1953, £1,500; from 1st April 1961, £1,650; from 31st December, 1968, £1,850.

The limits for unserviced houses and for flats were also increased from the same dates. The estimated average current subsidy of £106 a year represents two-thirds of the annual loan charges on £1,850 borrowed for a term of 50 years from the Local Loans Fund at 8½ per cent, which is the current rate of interest.

The comparable subsidy in 1953 of £57 a year is related to two-thirds of the annual loan charges on £1,500 borrowed for a term of 50 years from the Local Loans Fund at 5¼ per cent, the rate then applicable.

Is he also aware that because of the condition of the bridge it is costing CIE and all other hauliers a fortune? They have to use two buses or two trucks to get across this bridge. They are nearly as bad as the Fianna Fáil Party.

The answer to the first part of the question is “no”. The second part does not therefore arise.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Driving Licence Recognition.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is now, in view of our anticipated entry to the EEC, in a position to enter into negotiations with the British Government and the Northern Ireland authorities for mutual recognition of driving licences.

I would refer the Deputy to the reply given to Question No. 47 on the 8th April last. Since that date, however, the British Government have indicated that they are not prepared to enter into negotiations on this matter at this stage.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Road Haulage Vehicles.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is aware that at least one Irish road haulage vehicle laden with cargo which crossed to France by sea ferry was refused permission to land because its road worthiness did not come up to the standards required by the EEC; and if he will ensure that all steps as may be necessary will now be taken to bring all Irish road haulage vehicles, particularly those which may be used in international trade, up to the standards required in EEC countries.

I am not so aware. Vehicle regulations made under the Road Traffic Act, 1961, prescribe standards of roadworthiness for vehicles in use on our roads. Enforcement of the regulations is a matter for the Garda Síochána.

MainHeading.P: Our vehicle regulations were framed to conform with those of other European countries and to take account of the terms of the United Nations Convention on Road Traffic, 1949, to which we have acceded. The convention provides for uniform conditions under which vehicles may circulate internationally irrespective of any specific requirements imposed on member states of the EEC. If vehicles in use in this country comply with the roadworthiness requirements of our vehicle regulations they should have no difficulty as regards circulation in European countries including those of the EEC.
It is intended as far as is practicable to harmonise this country's vehicle regulations with any directives which may be issued by the EEC from time to time in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Speed Limit Signs.

asked the Minister for Local Government if he will increase in size the repeater speed limit sign to at least 12 inches in diameter.

The provision of traffic light signals is a matter for the local authority acting at the request, or with the consent, of the Garda Commissioner and my Department is involved only in so far as road fund moneys may be used to finance the installation of such signals. I understand that there are traffic light signals at Kill-o'-the-Grange crossroads. The Deputy may have in mind the junction of Kill Avenue/Abbey Road/Rochestown Avenue. MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Location of Road Signs.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is aware that many road signs indicating road dangers ahead are placed too near to the part of the road where the danger exists to be effectively of value to road users; and if he will inquire into this matter with a view to ensuring that these signs are located to provide the best advance warning of dangers ahead.

I am not so aware. The provision of traffic signs, including their location, is a matter for the road authority acting at the request, or with the consent, of the Garda Commissioner. In October, 1962, my Department issued general directions regarding the provision of traffic signs. These directions included a recommendation that danger warning signs should, as far as possible, be sited 100/200 yards from the intersection or hazard indicated, the actual distance to be determined having regard to the prevailing speed of traffic on the road, alignment, etc.

Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware of the practice of county councils of erecting road notices on roads when repairs are being carried out and leaving them there long after the repairs are completed with the result that signs put up for the purpose of notifying that repairs are in progress are often ignored particularly by tourists who get sick of seeing notices saying “Danger ahead” where in fact there is no danger at all? Could the Minister do something about that?
Yes, I shall look into that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Bay Preservation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if, in view of obvious public concern, including that of his predecessor, he will review plans for Dublin Bay and ensure that natural amenities are preserved.

The primary responsibility for the planning of the physical future of Dublin, including the preservation of the amenities of Dublin Bay, is vested by law in Dublin Corporation. The corporation's policies and development objectives are set out in the Dublin Draft Development Plan, 1968, which was on public display for almost four months last year. Before the plan is finally adopted, the corporation are obliged to consider all objections and representations received regarding it. I understand that over 1,400 objections or representations regarding the Dublin Bay area were received by the corporation and that these are at present being considered.

It is a matter for the corporation to decide whether any changes or modifications to the draft plan are required as a result of consideration of these objections and representations. Once the development plan is made, I would have power to require that it should be varied in respect of matters and in a manner specified by me, but at this stage it would obviously be premature for me to suggest that such action might be called for.

I understand that the bulk of the objections and representations received by Dublin Corporation in relation to Dublin Bay are concerned with the long-term proposals for reclamation and development in the port area which were published by the Dublin Port and Docks Board some years ago. I think I should make clear that these proposals were in outline form and were not intended to represent a definitive plan for the port area.

MainHeading.P: The draft development plan prepared by the corporation does not involve acceptance of these proposals. As the Deputy is probably aware, the Port and Docks Board have not yet completed the preparation of their definitive long-term plans. When these are available, they will of course have to be very carefully considered by the Departments concerned and by the planning authority. For my part, the Deputy can rest assured that, as Minister with overall responsibility for physical planning, I will be concerned to ensure that any development that is undertaken in the port area will take full account of the extremely important amenity values of Dublin Bay as well as the other important planning considerations involved.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Continental Parcel Post.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs what the procedure is in relation to the dispatch to or collection by addresses of parcels from the Continent; whether any time limits are involved; and if he will detail them.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. G. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. G. Collins)
Speaker.P: All incoming parcels are presented to the customs authorities for examination and when cleared by the customs are delivered in normal course by my Department.

If the customs authorities require documents such as invoices or import licences to be produced before clearing a parcel, they request the addressee to do so within fourteen days. If he fails to do so a final notice is sent warning him that unless he takes action within seven days the parcel will be treated as having been refused. Refused parcels are normally returned to the senders by my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins

asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs when the recently damaged telephone kiosk on St. Pappin's Road, Dublin, will be restored to a serviceable condition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: It is expected that the kiosk on St. Pappin's Road will be restored within the next few days.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Post Office Giro.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if, in view of the periodic closure of commercial banks in this country, he will introduce through the Post Office network an effective bank giro system.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to the reply given on the 4th June, 1970, and add that I would be reluctant to assume that there will be periodic closures of the commercial banks in the future.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Post Office Savings Bank.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if any public announcement was made to the effect that private cheque lodgments by depositors would not be accepted by the Post Office Savings Bank; if so, when; and, if not, why.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The answer is “No”. It was not considered necessary to make any such announcement because it was generally well known that cheques drawn by members of the public would not be freely acceptable during the banks closure.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Sub-Post Office Burglaries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs in how many cases of burglaries at sub-post offices in recent times sub-postmasters were compelled to make good the losses incurred; and the amount of such losses paid by sub-postmasters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: During the past 12 months sub-postmasters were required to make good losses arising from burglaries in two cases and the mounts paid were £35 and £3 16s 5d respectively.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - RTE Colour Transmission.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs whether there is any proposal for the allocation by the Government of capital in respect of RTE's decision to transmit in colour; whether RTE have made any proposals to him in this matter; and whether they have indicated (a) their capital needs and (b) additional operating costs involved in colour transmission, and, if so, if he will give details.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The answer to each part of the question is “No”.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Television Licences.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Belton Mr. L. Belton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if he is aware that television licence holders whose licence renewal fell due prior to the date of introduction of an increased fee and who had not at the time of increase paid their renewal fee are being charged the increased amount of £6; and if he intends to have the period of licence in such cases extended by an appropriate time in order that no injustice may occur.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I am so aware but I am satisfied that no injustice is involved and, accordingly, I do not intend to take any action. The announcement of the revised fees which stated that all licences purchased on and from July 1st would be at the higher rates was made in June and allowed a fortnight for the renewal of expired licences at the lower rates.

MainHeading.Title: Housing Bill, 1970: From the Seanad (Resumed)

6. After “resident in the dwelling” to insert “or to his licensee or invitee”.
—(Deputy FitzGerald).

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Robert Molloy
Speaker.P: When I asked the House this morning to allow me further time to consider the amendment which Deputy FitzGerald had put down, I did so in recognition of the case he was making and because I did not consider that my own amendment fully covered the cases which I had intended would be covered. I accept that certain categories of people could be deemed to be committing a criminal offence as the amendment stood. If Deputy FitzGerald is now prepared to withdraw his amendment I should like to propose this amendment to my own amendment No. 7.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment (Summer Recess): Motion (Resumed).
MainHeading.P: Debate resumed on the following motion:
Go rachaidh an Dáil, nuair a éireoidh sí an 30 Iúil, 1970, ar athló go dtí an 28 Deireadh Fómhair, 1970.
That the Dáil, at its rising on the 30th July, 1970, shall adjourn until the 28th October, 1970.
—(The Taoiseach.)

Speaker.P: I cannot remember where I left off in this debate but I know I was making a passing reference to the attractions which I personally felt membership of the EEC had for this country. I heard a couple of remarks from the Labour benches at that time. I think it was Deputy Dr. O'Donovan who said: “Yes, head as fast as possible right into disaster.” Previous to that I heard Deputy O'Leary saying that the one party in this House which already had international connections was the Labour Party. I heard Deputy Keating speak on the subject a few days ago somewhere else. All the time I find it hard to understand the attitude of the Labour Party to the EEC and to the alternatives we have to follow if we decide not to pursue our application for membership of the EEC. I heard somebody pointing out to Deputy Keating on that occasion that the Irish Labour Party was unique in Europe, that every other socialist party in Europe is quite enthusiastic about membership of the EEC.
As a matter of fact that is not true.
Sweden, Austria.
They were referring to the present membership.
To the Six.
The British Labour Party is not known to be that enthusiastic.
The British Labour Party in my time at the Council of Europe almost crawled to get into the EEC.
Ask Harold Wilson.

As far as I know their attitude has not changed except that when the balance of payments was corrected in Britain it then of course started to harden purely for the sake of making the best possible bargain.

Apart from the fact that we have in my view absolutely no alternative in this country if Britain goes into the Common Market except to follow, I see considerable attractions for this country in membership of the EEC. I do not intend to go into these in detail. There have been long debates on this and it can be gone into in considerable detail when we resume after the recess. If this Government do not resume another one will. I do not know what answer members of the Labour Party have to our over-dependence on a single market—the British market— where do we go from there if we do not go in.

It is all right to cry about the position of the 20-acre or the 30-acre farmer in the West of Ireland, that he will disappear. What farmer of 30 years of age or under today will accept the conditions endured by his forefathers? I agree with Deputy Keating that people should be told the truth. They should be told they will not continue to exist as 20-or 30-acre farmers. They could not possibly. They will not accept these standards. Either they will continue as part-time farmers, as the Minister for Lands has suggested, with a job in industry or the size of the farms must be increased and the number of farmers reduced. This is inevitable if the standard of living acceptable in the future is to be arrived at. Undoubtedly, these small farmers were wonderful people but the main wonder about them is that they endured for so long the hardships that are inevitably associated with farms of this size.

MainHeading.P: I and many people at the present time are concerned about the position whereby according to the law of the land people are compelled to insure their motor cars. At present there are thousands of people driving around this country with no insurance. The sooner the Taoiseach and the responsible Minister appreciate this the better. This is no fault of the car owners concerned and I say that they should not be summoned because they have failed absolutely to get cover. The Minister does not seem to be overconcerned about this and the Taoiseach does not seem to be overconcerned about it.

There should have been an inquiry into the problem long ago. Nobody knows what people are going through. As far as I can see, there is no solution except to keep your head in the sand. I have great sympathy for people involved in this and for the people from whom the insurance companies are demanding enormous sums before they will insure them. The insurance companies and the insurance brokers are not satisfied with the situation either and they would welcome an inquiry. The whole thing has come to the point where it requires close investigation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Robert Molloy
Speaker.P: If the Deputy knows of any cases of owners who have failed to get insurance he should get these people to communicate with my Department.
Certainly, but the Minister will agree this is a very round-about way of dealing with the matter.
There is special provision for people who find themselves in this difficulty. We have a special bureau to deal with it.
They can be covered at rates which everybody cannot be expected to afford.
Not necessarily so.

In regard to the question of telephone tapping which was referred to by a number of speakers particularly, Deputy Blaney, I do not give a damn who taps my telephone. Deputy Blaney said that he believed his telephone was still being tapped and that the telephones of other Deputies were being tapped. He did not accept the assurance already given. He did not say he disbelieved the Taoiseach. He said a warrant was necessary and the Taoiseach had assured the House no warrants were given. He asked if this telephone tapping was taking place regardless of the fact that there was no warrant. I should like the Taoiseach to tell us if there is any machinery to determine whether or not this type of telephone tapping is going on without a warrant. Some people regard this as a serious thing but, as I say, I do not give a curse who listens to my telephone conversations because I am not afraid of anything that will arise out of them. However, if anybody is trying to undermine the security of this State I say his telephone should be tapped. Even if he is suspected of undermining the security of the State, I say his telephone should be tapped. Perhaps the Taoiseach could elaborate on this matter.

I do not disagree with everything which the two Deputies who are in bad odour with Fianna Fáil said. There is a good deal with which we can agree, and of course there is a great deal with which we would disagree. I agree with Deputy Boland when he says that there is not an awful lot of meaning to be attached to the word “solidarity”. The Minister for External Affairs should explain what he means by “solidarity” with the people in the North. I presume he means that he would exert whatever pressure is available to him on the British to do everything possible to ease the situation there. Neither should the Taoiseach make statements like “we will not stand idly by” without clarifying them. Words are very important and statements are very important and they should be self-explanatory.
